facts.text: Respondents are residents of Sehore, a town in the territory of the State of Bhopal at the material time.
Respondent 1 is the brother of the owner of Rajkumar Laboratories, Sehore, which manufactures drugs.
Prabhat Trading Company, Ahmedabad (Bombay State), placed order on January 26, 1955, for 4800 bottles of Mrugmadasav, an Ayurvedic preparation.
Rajkumar Laboratories prepared Mrugmadasav containing rectified spirit, paid Rs. 3600 excise duty to Bhopal State.
Permit obtained on July 28, 1955, authorising export of the preparation out of Bhopal State limits.
Motor truck belonging to second respondent engaged for transporting preparation from Sehore to Ahmedabad.
On July 29, 1955, Sub-Inspector Shintre stopped the motor truck at Dohad, Bombay State.
Truck found carrying 7073 bottles of various sizes labelled 'Mrugmadasav, Rajkumar Laboratories, Sehore', with legend 'contains 85.5 alcohol'.
Respondents 1 and 2 accompanying in jeep which also contained bottles of Mrugmadasav; both arrested.
Samples drawn in presence of Panchas, sent to Assistant Chemist, Drugs and Excise Laboratory, Baroda, and Principal, R.A. Poddar Ayurvedic College, Bombay.
Respondents and eight others prosecuted before Judicial Magistrate 1st Class, Dohad, under ss.65(a) and 66(1)(b) Bombay Prohibition Act.
Magistrate convicted respondent 1 under ss.65(a) and 66(1)(b), respondent 2 under s.65(a) r/w s.81; Sessions Court, Panch Mahals, Godhra confirmed.
Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No.1485/1958, dated January 9, 1959, acquitted respondents.
P. Parikh, Assistant Chemist, Baroda: samples contained 75.55 to 79.97% v/v ethyl alcohol; not an Asav preparation; fit for use as intoxicating liquor; not standard preparation.
M.Y. Lele, Principal R.A. Podar Ayurvedic College: no musk odour in sample; contents not Mrugmadasav; standard formula has 20 tolas musk in 6.5 seers; musk Rs.60-80/tola.

Ansare, Excise Inspector Sehore: alcoholic proof strength 150, 85.5% v/v alcohol, rest water; proprietary Ayurvedic with added alcohol, not self-generated; 50 tolas rectified spirit added to 4 tolas musk etc. (part disbelieved by Magistrate and Sessions).
Magistrate held preparation contained large % alcohol not self-generated, no musk, not standard Mrugmadasav, meant for consumption as intoxicant, not exempt u/ss.12,13.
High Court held State failed to prove liquor for consumption as intoxicant; no opinion from Board of Experts u/s.6A.

legal_issues.text: Whether the seized Mrugmadasav was intoxicating liquor not exempt under s.24A of Bombay Prohibition Act, i.e., fit for use as intoxicating liquor despite being labelled medicinal preparation.
Whether consultation with Board of Experts under s.6A is mandatory before prosecution under ss.65,66.
Whether Bhopal export permit and duty payment exempts from Bombay Prohibition Act prohibitions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Bottles contained intoxicating liquor, not genuine Mrugmadasav; import/transport/possession without permit prohibited u/ss.12,13; not exempt u/s.24A as fit for intoxicating use.
Burden on prosecution to prove not unfit for intoxicating use; s.6A consultation not mandatory.

respondent_arguments.text: Mrugmadasav is genuine Ayurvedic medicinal preparation; State must prove not medicinal/unfit for intoxicating use; burden on State.
Prosecution invalid without State Government opinion after consulting Board of Experts u/s.6A.
Bhopal duty paid, permit obtained; Prabhat Trading holds licence.

court_reasoning.text: Preparation contained 75.5% alcohol, excess of standard; no substantial musk (corroborated by price impossibility); other ingredients harmless; fit for intoxicating use even in normal dose; not saved by s.24A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not genuine Mrugmadasav; capable of intoxication without health danger.

court_reasoning.text: Burden on prosecution to prove infringement of ss.12,13; s.24A exception requires unfit for intoxicating use and compliance with s.59A limits.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High alcohol % exceeds s.59A; fit for use as intoxicant.

court_reasoning.text: s.6A requires constituting Board but no mandatory consultation for prosecution; presumption optional aid.
Bhopal permit/duty no defence; no Bombay licence produced u/s.11.

holdings.text: Seized preparation is liquor under s.2(24), prohibitions u/ss.12,13 apply, not exempt u/s.24A.
Consultation u/s.6A not condition precedent to prosecution.
Bhopal permit does not protect against Bombay law violation.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Bombay v. F.N. Balsara
precedents_cited.relevance: Upheld certain provisions; led to addition of s.24A.

precedents_cited.case_name: Fram Nusserswanji Balsara v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Declared parts of Act ultra vires, prompting amendments.

precedents_cited.case_name: D.K. Merchant v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court followed it on s.6A; SC disagreed.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Prohibition Act, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines liquor/intoxicant; imposes prohibitions on import/transport/possession; exceptions for unfit preparations; expert board; penalties.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal by special leave, set aside Bombay High Court acquittal order dated January 9, 1959, and restored convictions and sentences by Magistrate confirmed by Sessions Court: respondent 1 to 6 months RI + Rs.500 fine (3 months RI default); respondent 2 to 1 month RI + Rs.300 fine (1 month 15 days RI default).

key_quotes.text: "the preparation seized by the police was not saved by virtue of s.24A from the prohibitions contained in ss.12 and 13 of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "there is no obligation expressly imposed upon the State in any given case to consult the Board of Experts, nor can such a provision be implied."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A medicinal preparation containing a small percentage of alcohol may still be capable of intoxicating if taken in large quantities, but if consumption... is likely to involve danger to the health... it cannot be regarded as fit."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'fit for use as intoxicating liquor'.
